commit_message:
Sync c-h with loopback_devices() fix

PY3 bug in loopback_devices caused the related bug.  This patch syncs
just the relevant file to fix the bug into charmhelpers.

Change-Id: I5aacd16c2bd4957c49210e867dc76efa1a315ab4
Closes-Bug: #1804128
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-swift-storage refs/changes/09/619009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: output = check_output(cmd) if six.PY3: output = output.decode('utf-8') devs = [d.strip().split(' ') for d in output.splitlines() if d != '']
deleted_lines: devs = [d.strip().split(' ') for d in check_output(cmd).splitlines() if d != '']

subject: Clean MAC_Binding entries when (dis)associating a FIP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-26 13:50:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/ac4903f4861a27c1b20ad329d873b4c9aefc5e73', 'message': "WIP: Clean MAC_Binding entries when disassociating a FIP

When a FIP gets disassociated, the MAC_Binding entries in SB
database are not getting cleared. There's a use case (surely
more) where 2+ Logical Routers are connected to the external
network and different VMs want to talk through FIPs. In this
case if one FIP is reused (was previously used and removed/
disassociated), the old flows due to the MAC_Binding entry
will still be present and no action will be sent to
ovn-controller to update the ARP responder, thus the old MAC
is still used and the FIP is unreachable.

While the proper way to fix this should be making ovn-northd
or ovn-controller clearing/updating the MAC_Binding entries
upon new NAT rules creation, this patch is a workaround to
remove whatever MAC_Binding entries are related to that FIP
when this gets disassociated.

Details about the bug reported in OVS ML at [0].

TODO: tests

[0] https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-October/047604.html

Change-Id: Ic04fcbe332adf030ab0ee3aad3a94ad874b18c9a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-10-29 11:58:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/bae8937beefd0c55ee9053c0ee44fc47311daa1b', 'message': "WIP: Clean MAC_Binding entries when (dis)associating a FIP

When a FIP is assigned to a port, it may happen that it was
previously used by another FIP or gateway port and an entry
in MAC_Binding table exits. If that's the case, the ARP
responder will answer with the wrong MAC address and the FIP
will then be unreachable.

In order to be on the safe side, this patch is deleting all
MAC_Binding entries upon association or disassociation of a
FIP as a workaround. The proper way to fix this should be
making ovn-northd or ovn-controller clearing/updating the
stale entries upon new NAT rules creation.

Details about the bug reported in OVS ML at [0].

TODO: tests

[0] https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-October/047604.html

Change-Id: Ic04fcbe332adf030ab0ee3aad3a94ad874b18c9a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Clean MAC_Binding entries when (dis)associating a FIP

When a FIP is assigned to a port, it may happen that it was
previously used by another FIP or gateway port and an entry
in MAC_Binding table exits. If that's the case, the ARP
responder will answer with the wrong MAC address and the FIP
will then be unreachable.

In order to be on the safe side, this patch is deleting all
MAC_Binding entries upon association or disassociation of a
FIP as a workaround. The proper way to fix this should be
making ovn-northd or ovn-controller clearing/updating the
stale entries upon new NAT rules creation.

Details about the bug reported in OVS ML at [0].

[0] https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2018-October/047604.html

Change-Id: Ic04fcbe332adf030ab0ee3aad3a94ad874b18c9a
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/84/613584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NATEntryDeleteEvent(row_event.RowEvent): """Row event - NAT 'dnat_and_snat' entry deleted This happens when a FIP is removed. """ def __init__(self, driver): self.driver = driver table = 'NAT' events = (self.ROW_DELETE) super(NATEntryDeleteEvent, self).__init__( events, table, (('type', '=', 'dnat_and_snat'),)) self.event_name = 'NATEntryDeleteEvent' def run(self, event, row, old): self.driver.fip_removed(row.external_ip) self._fip_remove_event = NATEntryDeleteEvent(driver) self._lsp_update_down_event, self._fip_remove_event]) helper.register_table('MAC_Binding')

commit_message:
Support Ironic Inspector dnsmasq PXE filter

The dnsmasq PXE filter [1] provides far better scalability than the
iptables filter typically used. Inspector manages files in a dhcp-hostsdir
directory that is watched by dnsmasq via inotify. Dnsmasq then either
whitelists or blacklists MAC addresses based on the contents of these
files.

This change adds a new variable, ironic_inspector_pxe_filter, that can
be used to configure the PXE filter for ironic inspector. Currently
supported values are 'iptables' and 'dnsmasq', with 'iptables' being the
default for backwards compatibility.

[1]
https://docs.openstack.org/ironic-inspector/latest/admin/dnsmasq-pxe-filter.html

Implements: blueprint ironic-inspector-dnsmasq-pxe-filter
Change-Id: I73cae9c33b49972342cf1984372a5c784df5cbc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/15/587915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Adds support for the `Ironic Inspector dnsmasq PXE filter <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic-inspector/latest/admin/dnsmasq-pxe-filter.html>`__ that provides improved scalability over the default IPTables PXE filter. This can be enabled by setting ``ironic_inspector_pxe_filter`` to ``dnsmasq``.

commit_message:
Set "no_log" for "databases user and setting permissions" tasks

At the moment the "databases user and setting permissions" task for
designate and nova leaks the database_password because of the use
of with_items:

---snip---
TASK [nova : Creating Nova databases user and setting permissions] *********************************************************
ok: [x -> y] => (item={u'database_password': u'password', u'database_name': u'nova', u'database_username': u'nova'})
ok: [x -> y] => (item={u'database_password': u'password', u'database_name': u'nova_cell0', u'database_username': u'nova'})
ok: [x -> y] => (item={u'database_password': u'password', u'database_name': u'nova_api', u'database_username': u'nova_api'})
---snap---

Change-Id: I141e4153223c8772c82a31d81e58057ce266c0b9
Co-authored-by: Bernd Müller <mueller@b1-systems.de>

commit_message:
Add glance-cache support

Glance cache is used to keep a locally cache image
in the glance_api service.
Is an usefull service when an image is commonly used
to speed times between pulling from storage backend
and send to nova.

Change-Id: I8e684cc10e4fee1cb52c17a126e3b11f69576cf6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/04/618804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Add support to configure glance-cache, enabled with ``enable_glance_image_cache`` and configure cache size with ``glance_cache_max_size``.

commit_message:
zuul: Move legacy jobs to project

Implement part of step one of the zuulv3 migration guide: move the
purely nova projects to the nova repo [1]. This does not migrate any
jobs used in other projects nor does it convert what is migrated to use
the new 'devstack' or 'devstack-tempest' base jobs. Both of these steps
should be done separately.

What's migrated:

- experimental:
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-lvm (renamed to nova-lvm)

What's dropped:

- experimental:
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-lxc (no one's using this)
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-wsgi-full (WSGI is the default since Pike)

What's still to be migrated, here or to other projects:

- check:
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-cells
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-ceph
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-linuxbridge
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multinode-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-nova-next-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration
  - ironic-tempest-dsvm-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron
- gate:
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-cells
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron
- experimental:
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-v20-api
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-nova-next
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-dvr-multinode-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-dvr-ha-multinode-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-scenario-multinode-lvm-multibackend
  - ironic-tempest-dsvm-pxe_ipa-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-os-vif
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-nova-libvirt-kvm-apr
  - legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-zero-downtime
  - ironic-tempest-dsvm-multitenant-network
  - ironic-tempest-dsvm-ipa-resourceclasses-partition-pxe_ipmitool-tinyipa
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-nfs
  - legacy-tripleo-ci-centos-7-nonha-multinode-oooq
  - legacy-barbican-simple-crypto-dsvm-tempest-nova
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-py35-full-devstack-plugin-ceph
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-pg-full
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full-opensuse-423
  - legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-oslo.versionedobjects

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html#legacy-job-migration-details

 Conflicts:
	.zuul.yaml

NOTE(melwitt): The conflicts are becase the nova-dsvm-base job does not exist
in Pike.

Change-Id: I41b03a34795efe139d5911c605cdbd3c47a2f059
(cherry picked from commit 0db7b77b4615f25217ad646b2e4082994e8dfb73)

commit_message:
monasca-agent: fix references in service files

Some references in the monasca-agent service files still
used upstream service names to reference services. As a result
of this, the PartOf references from the component services
were unresolvable, causing them not to get restarted upon
restarting openstack-monasca-agent.target.

Change-Id: I7bbfb77466964b10edec6f595feb68ccf2eeaa79

commit_message:
Deprecate auth_uri option

Option auth_uri from group keystone_authtoken is deprecated[1].
Use option www_authenticate_uri from group keystone_authtoken.

[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508522/

Change-Id: I68e4c9e81b8f17ec076a03376342e7b166efbe44
Implements: blueprint deprecate-auth-uri-option

commit_message:
remove unused methods from CommonDbMixin

The register_model_query_hook and _apply_dict_extend_functions methods
from CommonDbMixin is not being used by consumers today. This patch
removes them and updates any doc references as well.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I3e72d7f33f5a7b0c9c023295302929410f94eefb

subject: Fix neutron resource cleanup after ml2/ovs migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-20 10:36:24.000000000', 'files': ['migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/ovn-migration.yml', 'migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/migration/defaults/main.yml', 'migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/delete-neutron-resources/defaults/main.yml', 'migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/delete-neutron-resources/tasks/main.yml', 'migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/delete-neutron-resources/templates/delete-neutron-resources.sh.j2', 'migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/migration/tasks/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/4ea65133984caec42906c0566dd751f593ca8711', 'message': 'Fix neutron resource cleanup after ml2/ovs migration

The migration script "delete-neutron-resources" was being
executed on controller-0 instead of the undercloud node regardless
of the defer_to:localhost ansible setting.

In that controller ~/overcloudrc does not exist, so the cleanup
was failing silently.

This commit moves the cleanup to a separate role that we tie
to localhost (undercloud) from ovn-migration.yml

Closes-Bug: #1804194

Change-Id: I05f2411604ba01d170440ac655491a624f98aafc
'}]
commit_message:
Fix neutron resource cleanup after ml2/ovs migration

The migration script "delete-neutron-resources" was being
executed on controller-0 instead of the undercloud node regardless
of the defer_to:localhost ansible setting.

In that controller ~/overcloudrc does not exist, so the cleanup
was failing silently.

This commit moves the cleanup to a separate role that we tie
to localhost (undercloud) from ovn-migration.yml

Closes-Bug: #1804194

Change-Id: I05f2411604ba01d170440ac655491a624f98aafc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/83/618983/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: - include_tasks: delete-neutron-resources.yml delegate_to: localhost when: ovn_central is defined tags: - cleanup-neutron-resources

commit_message:
pci-passthrough-whitelist: allow devname regexps

devname may vary depending on physical slots network adapters have been
added to. This patch allows to pass a regular expression to find the
proper device name (ie. "enp(131|216)s0f1").

Any other regular expression special character is also allowed (ie. $,
\b, ^, etc.)

Change-Id: Ic87d53f23516013b4b96c5841e385a7747e149b3
Closes-Bug: 1786283
Signed-off-by: Alvaro Uria <alvaro.uria@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/37/590737/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re import jsondef get_network_device(): return os.listdir('/sys/class/net') def matches(pattern, list_of_strings): """ >>> matches(r'eth', ['eth1', 'veth', 'br1']) ['eth1', 'veth'] """ if type(pattern) != str \ or type(list_of_strings) != list: return [] regexp = re.compile(pattern) strings_matched = [string for string in list_of_strings if regexp.search(string)] return strings_matched def expand_network_devices(devices_json_whitelist, devicelist): """ >>> expand_network_devices('[{"devname": "eno2", ... "physical_network": "physnet1"}, ... {"devname": "enp13.s0f1", ... "physical_network": "physnet2"}]', ... commit_message:
Add interfaces from flags to adapter interface

When render_configs is called without an adapters_instance it used to
construct an adapters_instance which lacked any relation data. This
was, in effect, useless (the pre-existing docstring comment says as
much). Usually render_configs is called via render_with_interfaces
which inturn has gets its interface list excplicitly passed in.
However, this approach is not possible when needing to trigger a
config render from a generic layer as the generic layer does not know
which interfaces to pass.

This change adds code to dynamically build the interface list from
the flags which have been set already.

Change-Id: I1958226576c73d0ce0e9fd4c1423f86addadb454

commit_message:
Log stack environment output.

Print out the overcloud stack environment
parameters for debugging purposes, even though
the upgrade was performed correctly it's always
useful to know the content of the resource_registry
and other environment parameters.

Change-Id: I7431d3aacc219c551bd7b262dca189d94d4f1d5c

commit_message:
Add nrpe support

Parses services() available, and uses charmhelpers' haproxy checks to
set default checks for Heat. By enabling nrpe-external-master interface,
we also allow hacluster subordinate application to be monitored for
check_crm and pacemakerd.

Change-Id: I4ad2b1c514099f9b6fe352cdab65587780915e5c
Closes-Bug: 1664745
Signed-off-by: Alvaro Uria <alvaro.uria@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Install the timezone package by default

The timezone package is required in order to have the containers report
correct time the timezone package is required. This change install the
tz package across all of the distros we support.

Change-Id: I2aa2561cc6e2c71db0a16590f5d9dbab24b393d2
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2795982ba3b96e1ec3eae961d6e680adba314bfc)

commit_message:
Rename kuryr-status to kuryr-k8s-status

As there's another kuryr-status binary in kuryr repo this creates issues
when creating packags out of the repo and could get confusing, therefore
I'm renaming this one.

Change-Id: I4b958d53c6530dd5099b3ac1dbcde4648055ff38

commit_message:
Add test for host_only networks and ensure network ordering

The `host_only` network option did not have a functional test, this
change adds one so that the mv-extra interface will now run with this
which will ensure its functional when enabled. The "nspawn_combined_networks"
also had an issue where the first network in the container config could
be something other than the nspawn container network. This would shift
the gateway from the mv-nspawn and to whatever was defined first. A
change to the "nspawn_combined_networks" will now ensure
"nspawn_networks" is referenced first.

Depends-On: Ic280db301ce44b98ac35c8911999dec5fa263a29
Change-Id: Id20afab8b705f6528ba5575ee4704c1661e6e65c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit b2df99498c7a0c775ac13edcf3136e5b2dbefcb5)

The current network creation loop would allow a user to create duplicate

commit_message:
Add a guard so we don't allow for duplicate config

The current network creation loop would allow a user to create duplicate
configs within a container and that can break parts of an environment.

Change-Id: I3585422fb134eec5ef2532515a6cda463b239f7c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 0b9d6a4178103ecdd2bf2b82071420dc771fafbf)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-nspawn_container_create refs/changes/65/616165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: systemd_networkd_prefix: "nspawn_container" systemd_interface_cleanup: true {% set seen_networks = [] %} {# All nspawn_networks and container_extra_networks will be iterated over. #} {# If a device is found, a networkd config will be generated for it. #} {% set netname = value.interface | default('mv-' + value.bridge.split('br-')[-1]) %} {% set _network = {'interface': 'mv-' + netname} %} {% if netname not in seen_networks %} {% set _ = seen_networks.append(netname) %} {% if value.address is defined %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('address', value.address) %} {% if (value.netmask is defined) and (_network.address != 'dhcp') %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('netmask', value.netmask) %} {% set prefix = (value.address + '/' + value.netmask) | ipaddr('prefix') %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('address', [value.address + '/' + prefix | string]) %} {% endif %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('usedns', (value.usedns | default(true) | bool) | ternary('yes', 'no')) %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('static_routes', value.static_routes | default([])) %} {% if value.gateway is defined %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('gateway', value.gateway) %} {% endif %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('mtu', value.mtu | default(1500 | string)) %} {% set _ = _networks.append(_network) %}
deleted_lines: {% if value.interface is defined %} {% set _network = {'interface': 'mv-' + value.interface} %} {% else %} {% set _network = {'interface': 'mv-mv-' + value.bridge.split('br-')[-1]} %} {% endif %} {% if value.address is defined %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('address', value.address) %} {% if (value.netmask is defined) and (_network.address != 'dhcp') %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('netmask', value.netmask) %} {% set prefix = (value.address + '/' + value.netmask) | ipaddr('prefix') %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('address', [value.address + '/' + prefix | string]) %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('usedns', (value.usedns | default(true) | bool) | ternary('yes', 'no')) %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('static_routes', value.static_routes | default([])) %} {% if value.gateway is defined %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('gateway', value.gateway) %} {% endif %} {% set _ = _network.__setitem__('mtu', value.mtu | default(1500 | string)) %} {% set _ = _networks.append(_network) %}

commit_message:
Add missing user defined interface support

Macvlan interfaces can have a user defined interface within the host
config. This change ensures that the capability, which is documented in
the nspawn_host role, is actually functional.

Change-Id: I083042a791d9213b9b1872a239dc18dc6c7ae46e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit d01150301e2dcb7119392be693e168f8599cf6df)
(cherry picked from commit 5949f382cedb3e4b3cdb11ef3b059e313789475f)

added_lines: Show share server ========================== .. rest_method:: GET /v2/{tenant_id}/share-servers/{share_server_id} Shows a share server. Response codes -------------- .. rest_status_code:: success status.yaml - 200 .. rest_status_code:: error status.yaml - 400 - 401 - 403 - 404 Request ------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - tenant_id: tenant_id_path - share_server_id: share_server_id Response parameters ------------------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - id: id_14 - project_id: project_id_7 - status: status_15 - backend_details: backend_details - share_network_id: share_network_id_6 - share_network_name: share_network_name - host: host_8 - created_at: created_at_11 - updated_at: updated_at_6 Response example ---------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/share-server-show-response.json :language: javascript .. rest_method:: GET /v2/{tenant_id}/share-servers/{share_server_id}/detailsResponse parameters are backend specific. Each backend can store any key-value information that it requires. For example, the generic backend driver might store the router ID.
deleted_lines: .. rest_method:: GET /v2/{tenant_id}/share-servers/{share_server_id}/detail.. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - id: id_14 - project_id: project_id_7 - status: status_15 - backend_details: backend_details - share_network_id: share_network_id_6 - share_network_name: share_network_name - host: host_8 - created_at: created_at_11 - updated_at: updated_at_6

commit_message:
Add tenks-deploy.sh dev script

tenks-deploy.sh deploys a minimal virtualized baremetal test cluster
locally. It also adds it to the overcloud-base CI job. To make the new
CI job work, we need to configure the firewall on the test machine to
allow the baremetal machines to communicate with the openstack services.

Change-Id: I7487a2606cf0bac71c5c63db41b2b518a6f6398b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615939
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/618003
Story: 2004297
Task: 27850
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/39/601239/35 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- # This file holds the config given to Tenks when running `tenks-deploy.sh`. It # assumes the existence of the bridge `breth1`. node_types: type0: memory_mb: 1024 vcpus: 1 volumes: - capacity: 2GB physical_networks: - physnet0 specs: - type: type0 count: 2 ironic_config: resource_class: test-rc nova_flavors: - resource_class: test-rc node_type: type0 physnet_mappings: physnet0: breth1

subject: DNM: Make nova tests pass with externalized placement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-24 12:17:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/70782ac2a8c7b3434f866b8b3564fae3acfa6397', 'message': 'DNM: Make nova tests pass with externalized placement

These changes are an exploration of what it would take to get nova
"working" with placement code that comes from somewhere else. Not
because there's a plan to do anything immediately but because doing
experiments in advance helps to uncover issues so we can think about
it smoothly.

NOTE: Tests are not expected to pass, this is just for discussion:
nothing is managing the install of the special placement in the gate
so it will blow up.

What we have here is:

* recent nova master
* nova/api/openstack/placement removed (except for lib.py)
* nova/tests/{unit,functional}/api/openstack/placement removed
* https://github.com/EdLeafe/placement/pull/2 'pip install -e'
  into the local nova virtenv

And then the changes need to get both unit and functional tests
passing. As the diff (a consolidated one without file removes is at
[1]) shows, the changes are relatively minor and can be grouped into
three (overlapping) classes:

* things that directly access objects in placement
* things that need the PlacementFixture so they have access to a
  working placement API
* things that need access to the placement db, either because they
  want to use it directly, or because they are using the
  PlacementFixture with "real" data

The remaining changes are "we don't need placement here".

As a bonus this patch includes a slightly modified
nova/api/openstack/placement/wsgi.py which, if it is working
properly, allows a nova-placement-api WSGI app to run off the
nova.conf file, against the extracted placement code. Initial
diddling suggests it kind of works, but need to try with something
other than the built in server. Note that placement is still set up
to use either the [api_database]/connection or
[placement_database]/connection. Using the former if it is set and
falling back to the latter. This means that it would be possible to
use the placement code, but carry on with the "old" database, the
old config, and the wsgi script, if people wanted to do that sort of
thing.

The issues I'm able to identify by doing this (please follow up with
those that you think of) include:

* the nova/api/openstack/placement/lib.py file is used by both nova
  and placement for managing RequestGroup objects. However, as I
  understand things, there is, or will be some divergence on how
  these things are going to be used, so should be fine to have
  separate versions and not an actual "lib"

* The cmd and status checks that want the database need to have a
  future defined for them.

* The nova side PlacementFixture, which is a subclass of the
  placement side PlacementFixture, pretty much always needs a
  database, so it would make some sense to make that if not
  automatic then at least an option.

* The base test, when use db is true, uses the placement database.
  We should probably change that, even if we weren't going to
  extract placement.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/728735/

Change-Id: I0fada396e3c429bceeaccd321e4d82cb69e5265d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-08-24 13:23:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/89c2216b941250a73a262e451df9000e3c1a3c3a', 'message': 'DNM: Make nova tests pass with externalized placement

  via requirements

(Note that in order for code to be installed from git it has be installed
by pip directly, so tox.ini has been adjusted slightly to install
requirements.txt directly instead of having those things installed when
nova itself installed. This _may_ mean some tests pass in the gate.
We'll see.)

And then the changes need to get both unit and functional tests

The remaining changes are "we don't need placement here".

As a bonus this patch includes a slightly modified
nova/api/openstack/placement/wsgi.py which, if it is working
properly, allows a nova-placement-api WSGI app to run off the
nova.conf file, against the extracted placement code. Initial

to use either the [api_database]/connection or

use the placement code, but carry on with the "old" database, the
old config, and the wsgi script, if people wanted to do that sort of
thing.

The issues I'm able to identify by doing this (please follow up with
those that you think of) include:

* the nova/api/openstack/placement/lib.py file is used by both nova
  and placement for managing RequestGroup objects. However, as I
  understand things, there is, or will be some divergence on how

* The nova side PlacementFixture, which is a subclass of the

* The base test, when use db is true, uses the placement database.
  We should probably change that, even if we weren't going to
  extract placement.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/728735/

Change-Id: I0fada396e3c429bceeaccd321e4d82cb69e5265d

* nova/api/openstack/placement removed (except for lib.py)
* nova/tests/{unit,functional}/api/openstack/placement removed
* git+https://github.com/placementstuff/placement.git@cd/second-time installed
  via requirements

(Note that in order for code to be installed from git it has be installed
by pip directly, so tox.ini has been adjusted slightly to install
requirements.txt directly instead of having those things installed when
nova itself installed. This _may_ mean some tests pass in the gate.
We'll see.)

And then the changes need to get both unit and functional tests
passing. As the diff (a consolidated one without file removes is at
[1]) shows, the changes are relatively minor and can be grouped into
three (overlapping) classes:

* things that directly access objects in placement
* things that need the PlacementFixture so they have access to a
  working placement API
* things that need access to the placement db, either because they
  want to use it directly, or because they are using the
  PlacementFixture with "real" data

The remaining changes are "we don't need placement here".

As a bonus this patch includes a slightly modified
nova/api/openstack/placement/wsgi.py which, if it is working
properly, allows a nova-placement-api WSGI app to run off the
nova.conf file, against the extracted placement code. Initial
diddling suggests it kind of works, but need to try with something
other than the built in server. Note that placement is still set up
to use either the [api_database]/connection or
[placement_database]/connection. Using the former if it is set and
falling back to the latter. This means that it would be possible to
use the placement code, but carry on with the "old" database, the
old config, and the wsgi script, if people wanted to do that sort of
thing.

The issues I'm able to identify by doing this (please follow up with
those that you think of) include:

* the nova/api/openstack/placement/lib.py file is used by both nova
  and placement for managing RequestGroup objects. However, as I
  understand things, there is, or will be some divergence on how
  these things are going to be used, so should be fine to have
  separate versions and not an actual "lib"

* The cmd and status checks that want the database need to have a
  future defined for them.

* The nova side PlacementFixture, which is a subclass of the
  placement side PlacementFixture, pretty much always needs a
  database, so it would make some sense to make that if not
  automatic then at least an option.

* The base test, when use db is true, uses the placement database.
  We should probably change that, even if we weren't going to
  extract placement.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/728735/

Change-Id: I0fada396e3c429bceeaccd321e4d82cb69e5265d

commit_message:
DNM: Make nova tests pass with externalized placement

These changes are an exploration of what it would take to get nova
"working" with placement code that comes from somewhere else. Not
because there's a plan to do anything immediately but because doing
experiments in advance helps to uncover issues so we can think about
it smoothly.

What we have here is:

* recent nova master
* nova/api/openstack/placement removed (except for lib.py)
* nova/tests/{unit,functional}/api/openstack/placement removed
* git+https://github.com/placementstuff/placement.git@cd/second-time installed
  via requirements

(Note that in order for code to be installed from git it has be installed
by pip directly, so tox.ini has been adjusted slightly to install
requirements.txt directly instead of having those things installed when
nova itself installed. This _may_ mean some tests pass in the gate.
We'll see.)

And then the changes need to get both unit and functional tests
passing. As the diff (a consolidated one without file removes is at
[1]) shows, the changes are relatively minor and can be grouped into
three (overlapping) classes:

* things that directly access objects in placement
* things that need the PlacementFixture so they have access to a
  working placement API
* things that need access to the placement db, either because they
  want to use it directly, or because they are using the
  PlacementFixture with "real" data

The remaining changes are "we don't need placement here".

As a bonus this patch includes a slightly modified
nova/api/openstack/placement/wsgi.py which, if it is working
properly, allows a nova-placement-api WSGI app to run off the
nova.conf file, against the extracted placement code. Initial
diddling suggests it kind of works, but need to try with something
other than the built in server. Note that placement is still set up
to use either the [api_database]/connection or
[placement_database]/connection. Using the former if it is set and
falling back to the latter. This means that it would be possible to
use the placement code, but carry on with the "old" database, the
old config, and the wsgi script, if people wanted to do that sort of
thing.

The issues I'm able to identify by doing this (please follow up with
those that you think of) include:

* the nova/api/openstack/placement/lib.py file is used by both nova
  and placement for managing RequestGroup objects. However, as I
  understand things, there is, or will be some divergence on how
  these things are going to be used, so should be fine to have
  separate versions and not an actual "lib"

* The cmd and status checks that want the database need to have a
  future defined for them.

* The nova side PlacementFixture, which is a subclass of the
  placement side PlacementFixture, pretty much always needs a
  database, so it would make some sense to make that if not
  automatic then at least an option.

* The base test, when use db is true, uses the placement database.
  We should probably change that, even if we weren't going to
  extract placement.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/728735/

Change-Id: I0fada396e3c429bceeaccd321e4d82cb69e5265d

commit_message:
DNM: Use external placement in nova-next

This is an experiment to see if we can get external placement
and a hacked up devstack running a successful nova-next.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/600162

commit_message:
Prevent create port forwarding to port which has binding fip

For dvr scenario, if port has a bound floating, and then create
port forwarding to it, this port forwarding will not work, due to
the traffic is redirected to dvr rules.

This patch restricts such API request, if user try to create port
forwarding to a port, check if it has bound floating IP first.
This will be run for all type of routers, since neutron should
not let user to waste public IP address on a port which already
has a floating IP, it can take care all the procotol port
numbers.

Closes-Bug: #1799137
Change-Id: I4ba4b023d79185f8d478d60ce16417d3501bf785
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/52/614452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class PortHasBindingFloatingIP(exceptions.InUse): message = _("Cannot create port forwarding to floating IP " "%(floating_ip_address)s (%(fip_id)s) with port %(port_id)s " "using fixed IP %(fixed_ip)s, as that port already " "has a binding floating IP.")

commit_message:
Update doc for vm_workload_consolidation strategy

Actually, the metric "cpu_util" and "memory.resident" are necessary
in vm_workload_consolidation.py, according to line 75. So modify
this document about this part.

added_lines: OpenStack Swift, local directory, remote SSH or S3 compatible storage or remote FTP or FTPS storage.FTP Storage Backup/Restore -------------------------- Freezer can use FTP to backup the data in fould on remote server. This option will turn any FTP server to backup storage. To use FTP storage specify "--storage ftp" And use "--container %path-to-folder-with-backups-on-remote-machine%" Also you should specify ftp-username, ftp-password and ftp-host parameters. ftp-port is optional parameter, default is 21. In order to use FTP to backup, "--storage ftp" and "--container %path-to-folder-with-backups-on-remote-machine%" options must be specified. Also ftp-username, ftp-password, ftp-host parameters must be supplied. ftp-port parameter is optional and Freezer use default ssh port 21 if not specified. Backup example: .. code:: bash sudo freezer-agent --path-to-backup [/data/dir/to/backup] \ --container /remote-machine-path/ \ --backup-name my-backup-name \ --storage ftp --ftp-username [ftp-user-name] \ --ftp-password [ftp-user-password] \ --ftp-host 8.8.8.8 \ --ftp-port 21 Restore example: .. code:: bash sudo freezer-agent --action restore \ --restore-abs-pat [/data/dir/to/backup] \ --container /remote-machine-path/ \ --backup-name my-backup-name \ --storage ftp \ --ftp-username [ftp-user-name] \ --ftp-password [ftp-user-password] \ --ftp-host 8.8.8.8 --ftp-port 21 FTPS Storage Backup/Restore --------------------------- Freezer can use FTPS to backup the data in fould on remote server. This option will turn any FTPS server to backup storage. To use FTPS storage specify "--storage ftps" And use "--container %path-to-folder-with-backups-on-remote-machine%" Also you should specify ftp-username, ftp-password and ftp-host parameters. ftp-port is optional parameter, default is 21. In order to use FTPS to backup, "--storage ftps" and "--container %path-to-folder-with-backups-on-remote-machine%" options must be specified. Also ftp-username, ftp-password, ftp-host parameters must be supplied. ftp-port parameter is optional and Freezer use default ssh port 21 if not specified. Backup example: .. code:: bash sudo freezer-agent --path-to-backup [/data/dir/to/backup] \ --container /remote-machine-path/ \ --backup-name my-backup-name \ --storage ftps \ --ftp-username [ftp-user-name] \ --ftp-password [ftp-user-password] \ --ftp-host 8.8.8.8 \ --ftp-port 21 Restore example: .. code:: bash sudo freezer-agent --action restore \ --restore-abs-pat [/data/dir/to/backup] \ --container /remote-machine-path/ \ --backup-name my-backup-name \ --storage ftps \ --ftp-username [ftp-user-name] \ --ftp-password [ftp-user-password] \ --ftp-host 8.8.8.8 --ftp-port 21
deleted_lines: OpenStack Swift, local directory, remote SSH or S3 compatible storage.

commit_message:
Set WORKDIR / in the dockerfiles

For some reason buildah is failing on images which already have a
WORKDIR set (such as the tempest image). This change sets the WORKDIR
to / to avoid this failure.

Change-Id: Id756000a3b24eac01292907ca8837a5f99c66678
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image refs/changes/42/617442/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
use neutron-lib for _model_query

The model_query module is in neutron-lib and the CommonDBMixin will
eventually be removed. This patch swiches use of the _model_query
method over to query_with_hooks from neutron-lib.

Change-Id: Ifb99db6a13a9e3ad89eb5e790d89bb4451510bee

commit_message:
use context manager from neutron-lib

The neutron.db.api.context_manager already references neutron-lib's
context manager; so consumers of it are already using neutron-lib. This
patch switches neutron's references to the context_manager over to
use neutron-lib's directly rather than that in neutron.db.api.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I6bd6283b4bcc018d1e0fcd0972ec4a4278b24f3e

commit_message:
suport multi discovery service

magnum will try to use discovery url in following order:
1. discovery url which is passed when create a cluster
2. discovery service endpoint in configuration
3. if configurated discovery endpoint is differnent from
   "https://discovery.etcd.io/new?size=%(size)d" and,
   use "https://discovery.etcd.io/new?size=%(size)d" as a backup
   service

Change-Id: Ib76e2e8ea00fc9eb825625b5ec908663d890ba10
Task: 26937
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/71/619171/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BACKUP_DISCOVERY_ENDPOINT_FORMAT = \ "https://discovery.etcd.io/new?size=%(size)d" def _get_discovery_url(self, endpoint_fmt, master_count): discovery_endpoint = endpoint_fmt % {'size': master_count} try: discovery_request = requests.get(discovery_endpoint) if discovery_request.status_code != requests.codes.ok: raise exception.GetDiscoveryUrlFailed( discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) discovery_url = discovery_request.text except req_exceptions.RequestException as err: LOG.error(err) raise exception.GetDiscoveryUrlFailed( discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) if not discovery_url: raise exception.InvalidDiscoveryURL( discovery_url=discovery_url, discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) return discovery_url discovery_endpoint_fmt = \ CONF.cluster.etcd_discovery_service_endpoint_format try: discovery_url = self._get_discovery_url( discovery_endpoint_fmt, cluster.master_count) except (exception.GetDiscoveryUrlFailed, exception.InvalidClusterDiscoveryURL): if discovery_endpoint_fmt != BACKUP_DISCOVERY_ENDPOINT_FORMAT: msg = 'invalid discovery endpoint fmt {}, use backup' \ 'discovery service {}' msg = msg.format(discovery_endpoint_fmt, BACKUP_DISCOVERY_ENDPOINT_FORMAT) LOG.warning(msg) discovery_url = self._get_discovery_url( BACKUP_DISCOVERY_ENDPOINT_FORMAT, cluster.master_count) cluster.discovery_url = discovery_url
deleted_lines: discovery_endpoint = ( CONF.cluster.etcd_discovery_service_endpoint_format % {'size': cluster.master_count}) try: discovery_request = requests.get(discovery_endpoint) if discovery_request.status_code != requests.codes.ok: raise exception.GetDiscoveryUrlFailed( discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) discovery_url = discovery_request.text except req_exceptions.RequestException as err: LOG.error(err) raise exception.GetDiscoveryUrlFailed( discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) if not discovery_url: raise exception.InvalidDiscoveryURL( discovery_url=discovery_url, discovery_endpoint=discovery_endpoint) else: cluster.discovery_url = discovery_url

commit_message:
[UDP] Update amphora agent api ref

This patch add apt ref for new udp api, as the exsit api is too specific
haproxy. And update some affected api either.

Change-Id: Ia56377ad76e37d0cf1a4811763c226639bfa807e
Story: 2003290
Task: 24237

Response: { 'message': 'Error disabling haproxy-04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a service', 'details': 'haproxy-04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a.service not found', } :: DELETE URL: https://octavia-haproxy-img-00328.local/v0.1/listeners/04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a (A listener protocol included in request json body file.) Response: { 'message': 'Error disabling octavia-keepalivedlvs-04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a service', 'details': 'octavia-keepalivedlvs-04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a.service not found', } Upload UDP listener configuration ------------------------------------- * **URL:** /*:version*/listeners/*:amphora_id*/*:listener*/udp_listener * **Method:** PUT * **URL params:** * *:listener* = Udp Listener UUID * *:amphora_id* = Amphora UUID * **Data params:** keepalived configuration file for the UDP listener * **Success Response:** * Code: 202 * Content: OK * **Error Response:** * Code: 500 * Content: Error enabling octavia-keepalivedlvs service * **Response:** | OK | Error enabling octavia-keepalivedlvs service * **Implied actions:** * Create a udp specific directories and scripts for healthmonitor and vrrp health check. * Attempt to run the udp listener process. **Notes:** The syntax of the uploaded configuration file should be guaranteed by jinja template in server side, as reference udp backend using keepalived to configure lvs which not support syntactical pre-check. And the comments in the configuration file (like resource id for tracking the associated resource in the specific configuration block) will be parsed out for udp health timing loop to send out the amphora heartbeat which includes Listener, pool and members status. **Examples:** * Success code 202: :: PUT URL: https://octavia-haproxy-img-00328.local/v0.1/listeners/d459b1c8-54b0-4030-9bec-4f449e73b1ef/04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a/udp_listener (Upload PUT data should be a raw keepalivedlvs.conf file.) JSON Response: { 'message': 'OK' } * Error code 500: :: JSON Response: { 'message': 'Error enabling octavia-keepalivedlvs service', } Get UDP listener configuration ---------------------------------- * **URL:** /*:version*/listeners/*:listener*/udp_listener * **Method:** GET * **URL params:** * *:listener* = UDP Listener UUID * **Data params:** none * **Success Response:** * Code: 200 * Content: keepalived lvs configuration file for the UDP listener * **Error Response:** * Code: 404 * Content: UDP Listener Not Found * **Response:** | # Config file for 7e9f91eb-b3e6-4e3b-a1a7-d6f7fdc1de7c | (cut for brevity) * **Implied actions:** none **Examples:** * Success code 200: :: GET URL: https://octavia-haproxy-img-00328.local/v0.1/listeners/7e9f91eb-b3e6-4e3b-a1a7-d6f7fdc1de7c/udp_listener Response is the raw keepalivedlvs.cfg: # Config file for 7e9f91eb-b3e6-4e3b-a1a7-d6f7fdc1de7c (cut for brevity) * Error code 404: :: JSON Response: { 'message': 'UDP Listener Not Found', 'details': 'No UDP listener with UUID: 04bff5c3-5862-4a13-b9e3-9b440d0ed50a', }

commit_message:
Add docker bridge ip option to the undercloud.conf

Add docker_bip option to the undercloud.conf in order
to easily override the value of: DockerNetworkOptions
through the undercloud.conf

Change-Id: Ibbf7c6101539bdf575c23295c1b9fa4bfc84cff7

commit_message:
Fix ipv6 URL formatting for pxe/iPXE

The first DHCPv6 related fix was not enough.

In testing, it appears that we were not correctly returning
the proper variables and formatting to enable the machine to
boot via IPv6.

Fixes values, wraps a bare IPv6 address as dicated by RFC standards,
and enhances unit tests.

Change-Id: I9ebfb1ff1ba53dd117988b5e2a7736e20d1041a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/79/614279/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ip_version == 4: self.config(tftp_server='192.0.2.1', group='pxe') elif ip_version == 6: self.config(tftp_server='ff80::1', group='pxe') 'opt_value': 'tftp://[ff80::1]/tftp-path' self.config(tftp_server='ff80::1', group='pxe') def _dhcp_options_for_instance_ipxe(self, task, boot_file, ip_version=4): self.config(tftp_root='/tftp-path/', group='pxe') if ip_version == 4: self.config(tftp_server='192.0.2.1', group='pxe') self.config(http_url='http://192.0.3.2:1234', group='deploy') self.config(ipxe_boot_script='/test/boot.ipxe', group='pxe') elif ip_version == 6: self.config(tftp_server='ff80::1', group='pxe') self.config(http_url='http://[ff80::1]:1234', group='deploy') if ip_version == 6: # NOTE(TheJulia): DHCPv6 RFCs seem to indicate that the prior # options are not imported, although they may be supported # by vendors. The apparent proper option is to return a # URL in the field https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5970#section-3 expected_boot_script_url = 'http://[ff80::1]:1234/boot.ipxe' expected_info = [{'opt_name': '!175,59', 'opt_value': 'tftp://[ff80::1]/tftp-path' '/fake-bootfile', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '59', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': ip_version}] elif ip_version == 4: expected_boot_script_url = 'http://192.0.3.2:1234/boot.ipxe' expected_info = [{'opt_name': '!175,67', 'opt_value': boot_file, 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '66', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '150', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '67', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': 'server-ip-address', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}] if ip_version == 6: # Boot URL variable set from prior test of isc parameters. expected_info = [{'opt_name': 'tag:!ipxe,59', 'opt_value': 'tftp://[ff80::1]/tftp-path' '/fake-bootfile', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': 'tag:ipxe,59', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': ip_version}] elif ip_version == 4: expected_info = [{'opt_name': 'tag:!ipxe,67', 'opt_value': boot_file, 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '66', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': '150', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': 'tag:ipxe,67', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': ip_version}, {'opt_name': 'server-ip-address', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': ip_version}] self.config(ip_version=4, group='pxe') self.config(ip_version=4, group='pxe') def test_dhcp_options_for_ipxe_ipv6(self): self.config(ip_version=6, group='pxe') boot_file = 'fake-bootfile' self.config(pxe_bootfile_name=boot_file, group='pxe') with task_manager.acquire(self.context, self.node.uuid) as task: self._dhcp_options_for_instance_ipxe(task, boot_file, ip_version=6)
deleted_lines: self.config(tftp_server='192.0.2.1', group='pxe') 'opt_value': 'tftp://192.0.2.1/tftp-path' def _dhcp_options_for_instance_ipxe(self, task, boot_file): self.config(tftp_server='192.0.2.1', group='pxe') self.config(http_url='http://192.0.3.2:1234', group='deploy') expected_boot_script_url = 'http://192.0.3.2:1234/boot.ipxe' expected_info = [{'opt_name': '!175,67', 'opt_value': boot_file, 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': '66', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': '150', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': '67', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': 'server-ip-address', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}] expected_boot_script_url = 'http://192.0.3.2:1234/boot.ipxe' expected_info = [{'opt_name': 'tag:!ipxe,67', 'opt_value': boot_file, 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': '66', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': '150', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': 'tag:ipxe,67', 'opt_value': expected_boot_script_url, 'ip_version': 4}, {'opt_name': 'server-ip-address', 'opt_value': '192.0.2.1', 'ip_version': 4}]

We switched to running the voting LVM driver job
from Ubuntu to CentOS because the "nfs-utils"
package on Ubuntu 16.04 lacked two bug-fixes [1][2]
required to test IPv6 exports. The kernel
package has been updated on Ubuntu 18.04 [3]
and the latest package has these fixes.

Switching back to Ubuntu will also help us
move faster towards our python3-first goal
since there are no plans to support python3
in the CentOS base repositories.

[1] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=4663c6481c294838260840d234fec7dfd3186451
[2] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=188354e57dd8476e66ce30d647180a106da29b88
[3] https://launchpad.net/nfs-utils/+packages

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611199/
Change-Id: I8928f7ef87b0ec53a6a65f5d8964b2eee885056d
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2018-10-31 20:26:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/aee0159205808d502608bbbaf4eb83406b7a5789', 'message': '[CI][LVM] Run the LVM job on Bionic Beaver

We switched to running the voting LVM driver job
from Ubuntu to CentOS because the "nfs-utils"
package on Ubuntu 16.04 lacked two bug-fixes [1][2]
required to test IPv6 exports. The kernel
package has been updated on Ubuntu 18.04 [3]
and the latest package has these fixes.

Switching back to Ubuntu will also help us
move faster towards our python3-first goal
since there are no plans to support python3
in the CentOS base repositories.

[1] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=4663c6481c294838260840d234fec7dfd3186451
[2] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=188354e57dd8476e66ce30d647180a106da29b88
[3] https://launchpad.net/nfs-utils/+packages

commit_message:
[CI][LVM] Run the LVM job on Bionic Beaver

We switched to running the voting LVM driver job
from Ubuntu to CentOS because the "nfs-utils"
package on Ubuntu 16.04 lacked two bug-fixes [1][2]
required to test IPv6 exports. The kernel
package has been updated on Ubuntu 18.04 [3]
and the latest package has these fixes.

Switching back to Ubuntu will also help us
move faster towards our python3-first goal
since there are no plans to support python3
in the CentOS base repositories.

[1] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=4663c6481c294838260840d234fec7dfd3186451
[2] http://git.linux-nfs.org/?p=steved/nfs-utils.git;a=commit;h=188354e57dd8476e66ce30d647180a106da29b88
[3] https://launchpad.net/nfs-utils/+packages

changed port in tools/sample_data.sh

With the removal of the Identity v2 API, keystone now runs on
port 5000, rather than on the port 35357 which was used earlier.

commit_message:
Handling invalid path of workspace register and move

This PS will fix the invalid value handling.
Error will be raised if no/blank value will be specified for
workspace register and workspace move for path parameter.

Change-Id: I0d9956cac27fd4dbb527fd865aa152e4724c01f9
Closes-Bug: #1799883
Partially-Implements: blueprint tempest-cli-unit-test-coverage

commit_message:
Document user options

User options have been available in keystone for a few releases but
there isn't any official documentation for them.

This commit add a general section to the administrator guide that
attempts to describe each options and its type.

Change-Id: Ib0cc07236ba9083c2a35bf8ac6444ccfd19b7219
Related-Bug: 1792026
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/23/618823/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================ Resource Options ================ A resource option is an attribute that can be optionally set on an entity in keystone. These options are used to control specific features or behaviors within keystone. This allows flexibility on a per-resource basis as opposed to settings a configuration file value that controls a behavior for all resources in a deployment. This flexibility can be useful for deployments is setting different authentication requirements for users. For example, operators can use resource options to set the number of failed authentication attempts on a per-user basis as opposed to setting a global value that is applied to all users. The purpose of this document is to formally document the supported resource options used in keystone, their intended behavior, and how to use them. User Options ============ ignore_change_password_upon_first_use ------------------------------------- Type: ``Boolean`` Control if a user should be forced to change their password immediately after they log into keystone for the first time. This can be useful for deployments that auto-generate passwords but want to ensure a user picks a new password when they start using the deployment. See the `security compliance documentation <identity-security-compliance.html>`_ for more details. ignore_password_expiry ---------------------- Type: ``Boolean`` Opt into ignoring global password expiration settings defined in ``keystone.conf [security_compliance]`` on a per-user basis. Setting this option to ``True`` will allow users to continue using passwords that may be expired according to global configuration values. See the `security compliance documentation <identity-security-compliance.html>`_ for more details. ignore_lockout_failure_attempts ------------------------------- Type: ``Boolean`` If ``True``, opt into ignoring the number of times a user has authenticated and locking out the user as a result. See the `security compliance documentation <identity-security-compliance.html>`_ for more details. lock_password ------------- Type: ``Boolean`` If set to ``True``, this option disables the ability for users to change their password through self-service APIs. See the `security compliance documentation <identity-security-compliance.html>`_ for more details. multi_factor_auth_enabled ------------------------- Type: ``Boolean`` Specify if a user has multi-factor authentication enabled on their account. This will result in different behavior at authentication time and the user may be presented with different authentication requirements based on multi-factor configuration. multi_factor_auth_rules ----------------------- Type: ``List of Strings`` Define a list of strings that represent the methods required for a user to authenticate.

convert py35 jobs to py3

Update the jobs that were explicitly using python 3.5 and have them
just use python 3 without specifying a minor version.

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-20 10:51:00.000000000', 'files': ['validations/undercloud-process-count.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations/commit/eec3c5e37dff6af57171b11661ba6eb3279107c8', 'message': "Fix the undercloud-process-count validation

After containerization of several services the `pgrep` call which should return
the number of running processes doesn't work anymore (since it's executed
outside of the container where the service is running)

This patch executes the `pgrep` command inside of the appropriate container.

Note: The validation in its current form cannot make a judgement for a

commit_message:
Fix the undercloud-process-count validation

After containerization of several services the `pgrep` call which should return
the number of running processes doesn't work anymore (since it's executed
outside of the container where the service is running)

This patch executes the `pgrep` command inside of the appropriate container.

Note: The validation in its current form cannot make a judgement for a
realistic limit for any given situation. For that reason, this validation will
always succeed with warning(s).

Change-Id: I0cb33babae2fc285fff7fd6638c578b39e630338
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit dd979247206b1f47f128c68cdc3ea5286dcd5df7)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-15 17:54:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/4b96bef1a46a89375b894ea6eaf74aad3eedcbe0', 'message': 'DNM - debug update_identifier for common deploy tasks

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-11-16 18:32:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/65d017ea5f28c0d0f6f16681c6ad187fa2b6e64e', 'message': 'Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

When using --skip-deploy-identifier, the UpdateIdentifier is set to
None.
Ansible doesn't see None as "", so we really need to test if the
variable is defined or not. That patches changes the logic to test that.
We also support the case where the variable is set to "", and consider
is as empty which means we want to skip the deploy/updates.
It is also doing it for the update playbooks which includes tasks from
commont deploy.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.
There is no need to also check if /var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json
file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

This fix the bug where --skip-deploy-identifier wasn't honored during
stack updates.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Hervé <therve@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sam Doran <sdoran@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

When using --skip-deploy-identifier, the UpdateIdentifier is set to
None.
Ansible doesn't see None as "", so we really need to test if the
variable is defined or not. That patches changes the logic to test that.
We also support the case where the variable is set to "", and consider
is as empty which means we want to skip the deploy/updates.
It is also doing it for the update playbooks which includes tasks from
commont deploy.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.
There is no need to also check if /var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json
file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

This fix the bug where --skip-deploy-identifier wasn't honored during
stack updates.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Hervé <therve@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sam Doran <sdoran@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924
(cherry picked from commit 5ac6d19f58f188328e6f850e63c65bb70eb1c4f7)

commit_message:
Consider root id is None in the database case

There are cases where ``root_provider_id`` of a resource provider is
set to NULL just after it is upgraded to the Rocky release. In such
cases getting allocation candidates raises a Keyerror.

This patch fixes that bug for cases there is no sharing or nested
providers in play.

Change-Id: I9639d852078c95de506110f24d3f35e7cf5e361e
Closes-Bug:#1799892

commit_message:
Add recreate test for bug 1799892

There are cases where ``root_provider_id`` of a resource provider is
set to NULL just after it is upgraded to the Rocky release. In such
cases getting allocation candidates raises a Keyerror.

This patch recreate that bug by simulating the situation by
inserting the records to the database directly.

Change-Id: Iaed912314f3e8fef2f46453a6bf12011702ae1dd
Related-Bug:#1799892
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/31/617031/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_get_allc_req_old_records(self): """Simulate an old resource provider record in the database that has no root_provider_uuid set and ensure that we still get that candidate returned. """ # Passing a non-existing resource provider UUID should return an empty # list rp_tbl = rp_obj._RP_TBL inv_tbl = rp_obj._INV_TBL alloc_tbl = rp_obj._ALLOC_TBL conn = self.placement_db.get_engine().connect() # First, set up a record for an "old-style" resource provider with no # root provider UUID. ins_rptbl = rp_tbl.insert().values( id=1, uuid=uuids.rp1, name='cn1', root_provider_id=None, parent_provider_id=None, generation=42, ) conn.execute(ins_rptbl) # Add VCPU(resource_class_id=0) inventory to the provider. ins_invtbl = inv_tbl.insert().values( id=1, resource_provider_id=1, resource_class_id=0, total=8, reserved=0, min_unit=1, max_unit=8, step_size=1, allocation_ratio=1.0, ) conn.execute(ins_invtbl) # Consume VCPU inventory ins_alloctbl = alloc_tbl.insert().values( id=1, resource_provider_id=1, consumer_id=uuids.consumer, resource_class_id=0, used=4 ) conn.execute(ins_alloctbl) # TODO(tetsuro): Bug#1799892: Fix this not to raise the KeyError # alloc_cands = self._get_allocation_candidates( # {'': placement_lib.RequestGroup( # use_same_provider=False, # resources={ # fields.ResourceClass.VCPU: 1 # } # )} # ) # # expected = [ # [('cn1', fields.ResourceClass.VCPU, 1)] # ] # self._validate_allocation_requests(expected, alloc_cands) # # expected = { # 'cn1': set([ # (fields.ResourceClass.VCPU, 8, 4) # ]), # } # self._validate_provider_summary_resources(expected, alloc_cands) self.assertRaises( KeyError, self._get_allocation_candidates, {'': placement_lib.RequestGroup( use_same_provider=False, resources={ fields.ResourceClass.VCPU: 1 } )} )

commit_message:
allow more recent puppet modules in metadata.json

Allow much newer puppet modules to be deployed when using automatic dependencies lookup.
This will allow deploying puppet5 and puppet6 compatible modules, and will prevent keeping back some core modules such as mysql.
The only exception is puppetlabs/rabbitmq which was left untouched, as this might require coordination with other openstack
puppet modules since puppetlabs/rabbitmq was handed over to puppet/rabbitmq (from Vox Pupuli) and is now version 8.4.0
(compared to the old 5.6.0 in the current requirement), and thus other openstack puppet modules should require the same module
to prevent module names collision.

Change-Id: I10fe1cf1429181ea3e6b325193be7b39773005b4

commit_message:
default to py3 and add fast8

- This change updates named envs to default to py3
- This change adds fast8 as an target that run
  pep8 on only the files that have changed.
- This change adds docs and releasenotes envs
  to default set and enables fast8 instead of pep8

Change-Id: If07f9331380aab1ec6da90e7b6b393509f6f3623
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookiecutter refs/changes/39/599239/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/sh # # A simple wrapper around flake8 which makes it possible # to ask it to only verify files changed in the current # git HEAD patch. # # Intended to be invoked via tox: # # tox -epep8 -- -HEAD # if test "x$1" = "x-HEAD" ; then shift files=$(git diff --name-only HEAD~1 | tr '\n' ' ') echo "Running flake8 on ${files}" diff -u --from-file /dev/null ${files} | flake8 --diff "$@" else echo "Running flake8 on all files" exec flake8 "$@" fi

subject: DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-15 19:04:35.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/l3_dvrscheduler_db.py', 'neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_dvr_router.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/dvr_local_router.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/router_info.py', 'neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/framework.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_agent.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_l3_agent_scheduler.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/dvr_edge_ha_router.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/dvr_edge_router.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f7f09c79e561931bd80b0b7e17faca54926102bd', 'message': 'DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network
Node SNAT Namespace should be cleared.

But the original FloatingIP setup in SNAT Namespace was not
cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491
(cherry picked from commit cd0cc47a6ab0f7968a8c24e9d477909c45e4ae87)
'}]
commit_message:
DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network
Node SNAT Namespace should be cleared.

But the original FloatingIP setup in SNAT Namespace was not
cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491
(cherry picked from commit cd0cc47a6ab0f7968a8c24e9d477909c45e4ae87)

commit_message:
Consider root id is None in the database case

There are cases where ``root_provider_id`` of a resource provider is
set to NULL just after it is upgraded to the Rocky release. In such
cases getting allocation candidates raises a Keyerror.

This patch fixes that bug for cases there is no sharing or nested
providers in play.

Change-Id: I9639d852078c95de506110f24d3f35e7cf5e361e
Closes-Bug:#1799892

commit_message:
Ansible json error callback plugin

This callback plugin will write any task errors (that are not
ignore_error: true) to a log file in JSON format.

In later patches, we can add the cli and workflows to make these errors
visible via the Mistral API.

Change-Id: I72a91473511f335f8a0e40c7a786ff927113f26a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/38/566938/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2018 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # Make coding more python3-ish from __future__ import (absolute_import, division, print_function) __metaclass__ = type DOCUMENTATION = ''' callback: json_error short_description: Write errors in JSON format to a log file description: - This callback writes errors in JSON format to a log file type: aggregate options: output_dir: name: json-error log file default: ansible-error.json description: Log file where to write errors in JSON format. env: - name: JSON_ERROR_LOG_FILE ''' import json from ansible.plugins.callback import CallbackBase class CallbackModule(CallbackBase): CALLBACK_VERSION = 2.5 CALLBACK_TYPE = 'aggregate' CALLBACK_NAME = 'json-error' def __init__(self, display=None): super(CallbackModule, self).__init__(display) self.errors = {} self.log_file = os.getenv( 'JSON_ERROR_LOG_FILE', 'ansible-error.json') def v2_playbook_on_stats(self, stats): with open(self.log_file, 'w') as f: f.write(json.dumps(self.errors)) def v2_runner_on_failed(self, result, ignore_errors=False): if not ignore_errors: host_errors = self.errors.setdefault(result._host.name, []) host_errors.append(result._result)

commit_message:
Provides detailed conductor information

In a large deployment with multiple ironic conductors incorporated,
nodes are distributed across conductors by hashring. Currently we
have no mechanism to know which conductor currently is serving a
given node.

This spec proposes providing support for retrieving such information
from ironic API.

In short:

* Add ``/v1/conductors`` to return the list of known conductors.
* Add ``/v1/conductors/{hostname}`` and ``/v1/nodes/{node_ident}/conductor``
  to return more detailed information.
* Update ``/v1/nodes*`` related APIs to include a ``conductor`` field
  which indicates the hostname where the conductor serving a node is
  running. Support node querying by conductor hostname.

Story: 1724474
Task: 10629
Change-Id: I7da04c1775132d4112acf3e1f3f1f19cf164a144

subject: Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-11-15 17:51:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/7b732d5736d9669da5fbe5841a3f0e5f769cfe03', 'message': 'DNM - debug update_identifier for common deploy tasks

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-11-16 13:50:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/34b98e108bd0d9c3b9bfd0d2969aab48879867b8', 'message': 'common-deploy-tasks: switch update_identifier to a boolean

When --skip-deploy-identifier, we force DeployIdentifier to be null.
The result is that update_identifier is not even set to "" but is really
empty:

update_identifier:

Ansible doesn't treat this as an empty variable but as a variable that
is set and set to something.
It can easily be reproduced with this playbook:

- hosts: localhost
  vars:
    update_identifier:
  tasks:
   - debug:
       msg: variable is not empty
     when: update_identifier|default(false) != ""
   - debug:
       msg: variable is empty
     when: update_identifier|default(false) == ""
   - debug:
       msg: variable is false
     when: not update_identifier|default(false)

ok: [localhost] => {
    "msg": "variable is not empty"
}
ok: [localhost] => {
    "msg": "variable is false"
}

So instead of testing if the variable != "", we should default to a
boolean and change the logic:
If update_identifier is set to False or if the Docker JSON files don't
exist, then we can run the common deploy tasks that configure containers
and such. Otherwise, we skip the nodes, as it is wanted by the operator
when using --skip-deploy-identifier.

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2018-11-16 15:07:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/67625271d281b3f808907fb298e579898696932e', 'message': "Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.
There is no need to also check if /var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json
file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

This fix the bug where --skip-deploy-identifier wasn't honored during
stack updates.

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2018-11-16 16:40:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/2c432e261f5e541089df8788ef3761b91bb7b5f2', 'message': 'Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

When using --skip-deploy-identifier, the UpdateIdentifier is set to
None.
Ansible doesn't see None as "", so we really need to test if the
variable is defined or not. That patches changes the logic to test that.
It is also doing it for the update playbooks which includes tasks from
commont deploy.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.
There is no need to also check if /var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json
file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

This fix the bug where --skip-deploy-identifier wasn't honored during
stack updates.

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2018-11-16 17:37:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/370910d40b3e5f074b4dab65617c5557fd21be5e', 'message': 'Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

When using --skip-deploy-identifier, the UpdateIdentifier is set to
None.
Ansible doesn't see None as "", so we really need to test if the

is as empty which means we want to skip the deploy/updates.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.

file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

commit_message:
Honor --skip-deploy-identifier in common deploy tasks for updates

To continue the work that was done in
I711dbb00a9c34dbd96ef179ef41bff281b0001d1, we also need to skip the common
deploy tasks if --skip-deploy-identifier is passed by the operator.

When using --skip-deploy-identifier, the UpdateIdentifier is set to
None.
Ansible doesn't see None as "", so we really need to test if the
variable is defined or not. That patches changes the logic to test that.
We also support the case where the variable is set to "", and consider
is as empty which means we want to skip the deploy/updates.
It is also doing it for the update playbooks which includes tasks from
commont deploy.

It is not replicating the exact condition as in deploy_steps_playbook.
There is no need to also check if /var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json
file is here because it has been created during the initial deployment.

This fix the bug where --skip-deploy-identifier wasn't honored during
stack updates.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Hervé <therve@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sam Doran <sdoran@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ibab17dcaeebea65135fca4f40562109c90f36c27
Related-Bug: #1796924

added_lines: - name: Debug update_identifier var debug: msg: "update_identifier is set to {{ update_identifier }}"

commit_message:
Fixed logstash file name for tempest

* The file getting generated is tempest.log under /home/zuul/
  tempest.log not tempest-output.log that's why it is not able
  to indexed in logstash.
* And tempest_log_file var is used twice in validate-tempest role
  and tempest.log is used at each place which also leads that
  tempest_output.log was never found in ci logs.

Related-Bug:#1802971

Change-Id: I9bb9f8bdd0a17d2a1481356caaf186ed6348f6ba

commit_message:
Use a shorter default domain name

Since https://review.openstack.org/615730 we default
to <hostname>.tripleodomain.example.com if hostname is
not set.

Some of the CI jobs use very long <hostname>'s, resulting
in the FQDN to be more than 63 characters long which is
the max for linux, see GETHOSTNAME(2).

Change the default to use: <hostname>.ooo.test instead.

Also, yamllint complain about indentation.

Closes-Bug: #1803703
Change-Id: If041b1c6e1da1d89d66ffafbbc6ab6c33bd80801
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/88/618588/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: undercloud_fqdn: "{{ ansible_hostname }}.ooo.test"

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: Ie69f0a6fa56fd1fceaa7893bece8b2735095216c
Related-Bug: 1801465
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/56/614956/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 2.0

commit_message:
Minimal construct plumbing for nova show when a cell is down

This patch sets the stage for modifying the behavior of nova show
which currently gives a 500 when the cell in which the instance
lives is down. The new behavior will return a partial construct
consisting of uuid, project_id, created_at from instance_mappings
table and user_id, flavor, image_ref and availability_zone info
from request_specs table.  Note that the rest of the keys will be
missing. This behavior will be enabled by passing a new enough
microversion, handling for which is introduced later in this series.

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Iaea1cb4ed93bb98f451de4f993106d7891ca3682
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/591658/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
